name: Mother
reviewBody: Wow! This is a strangely great and botched movie. Botched because it clearly cuts off. Great because it's riveting. Those were the shoulders that Martin Scorsese managed to climb on. What really stuck with me though were two things. Firstly: Jean Harlow, although now a household name, couldn't act for toffee. Or maybe she was badly directed and learned it later. Secondly: that mother (Beryl Mercer). What a character. She's an infantile old woman who cares for her own needs first, no matter how much harm she gets her men into. She would happily stand by her sons killing each other while she stood by clasping and wringing her hands, as long as it suited her vain necessities. She's very eerie, to me she's much more so than, say, Norman Bates or Hannibal Lecter. Unlike them, she's not just the offshoot, she's the root of all evil -- I think you ought to use the opportunity which only the silver screen can afford you, of getting so close without getting burned ...
